title: Liverpool's Jurgen Klopp admits reaching the EFL Cup semis backfired during their miserable January
text:
Sport Liverpool's Jurgen Klopp admits reaching the EFL Cup semis backfired during their miserable January The Reds won one of 10 games last month and the boss now thinks it would have been better to exit League Cup earlier Share Liverpool would have had a less hectic January if they had been out of the EFL Cup (Photo: Getty) Share   Thank you for subscribing!   
Liverpool 's title challenge imploded because they are not yet a top team... according to their own manager Jurgen Klopp. 
But the good news for despondent Reds fans is their boss believes there is no lack of quality within his squad, just the mental toughness required to be champions. 
And according to manager Klopp , it is only in the fires of a title-challenge meltdown that the lessons of what it takes to make the final step towards greatness can be learned. 
Speaking after a demoralising January where Liverpool won only one of 10 matches and lost all hope of winning a trophy this season, the German admitted his men don't yet know what it takes to be one of the sides at the top - and all the pressure that brings. On January 11, a Nathan Redmond goal beat Liverpool at St Mary's... (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) ...and it was the same result at Anfield in the semi's second leg, with Shane Long scoring (Photo: AFP/Getty) 
"We are not used to being a top team. "Maybe we have to be, but we are not used to being... we are not clever like Chelsea who will be 2-0 up and just finish a game, say (to their opponents) 'Now come and try something!'" he explained. 
"Did I learn anything new about them in the last few weeks? Yes. A lot of what I wanted to learn? No. But that is how it is. I am not one bit in doubt about the character of these players but of course we have to create mentality." 
For Klopp, the extraordinary momentum of collapse was a combination of things, with the inability to grind results out as Chelsea have done for much of the season a key factor. 
He has a frighteningly young side that he is building for the future, with the project viewed in terms of years, not just this season. Liverpool are recharging for the run-in at Spain's La Manga resort (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) 
The German says it was the toll taken by a fixture list which saw Liverpool play 13 matches in just 33 days over Christmas and the early weeks of the New Year that his inexperienced squad found most difficult to cope with. 
And he even hinted distractions such as runs into the later rounds of the EFL Cup are possibly better avoided. 
Asked what he learnt from such a difficult period, he replied with a smile: "December-January, (the fixtures) make it difficult. In December, we missed players and did not have the best schedule. It feels worse because of different cup competitions. Last Saturday's win over Spurs brought a miserable run to an end for the Reds (Photo: AFP/Getty) 
"We should have been out of the EFL Cup last year, and that would have meant two less defeats this year [both legs of the semi-final against Southampton] in a moment when we needed each second for bringing a player back from injury, for recovery, for training, all that stuff. 
"It didn't help, but that's how it is. 
"Chelsea were able to play the same team all the time. They left the EFL Cup when? Before it started? I don't remember them playing one game in that competition [Chelsea went out at the last-16 stage]. 
"Get rid of this.
